repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Post and Telecommunications
            Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Post and
            Telecommunications Technical Assistance Project for Guinea
            was satisfactory. The project achieved many of its
            objectives, its impact on institutional development has been
            substantial, sustainability is uncertain, and the
            performance of both the Bank and Borrower was satisfactory.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First, a
            ministry with vested interests in a public enterprise should
            not be in charge of the divestiture of the enterprise.
            Second, it is essential to assess the feasibility of social
            equity and universal coverage objectives during the design
            of post and telecommunications sector reform projects.
            Third, the best way to improve telecommunications service
            quality, coverage, and regulation is to open the sector to
            competition and not protect the incumbent company, whether
            public or private. Finally, if it is necessary to grant some
            exclusive rights, such rights should be precisely defined
            and granted for a limited period of time.

18156906.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Rule of law

repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Post and Telecommunications
            Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Post and
            Telecommunications Technical Assistance Project is to
            develop progressively a modern communications sector, which
            is essential for the development of the country's
            economy. The project has two major orientations: launching
            Societe des Telecommunications de Guinee (SOTELGUI) and
            Office de las poste guineenne (OPG) on a firm basis, by
            financing key appointments in administrative and operational
            positions, and reorganizing the Ministry as the policy-maker
            and regulator for the sector. The project includes the
            following components: (a) two years of assistance for
            institution building; (b) reorganization of the Ministry of
            Communication, particularly concerning its supervisory
            functions (planning, tariff and financial policies, social
            policy, service quality) and regulatory functions (frequency
            control, licenses to operate networks or to sell equipment);
            (c) the search for professional partners for SOTELGUI, in
            accordance with the Public Enterprise Sector Rationalization
            and Privatization Technical Assistance (PESERP)
            project's privatization framework (Cr. 2398-GUI); (d)
            engineering studies for priority telecommunications and
            postal investments; (e) a specialized training program for
            SOTELGUI and OPG; (f) building renovation and provision of
            office equipment; and (g) supply of spare parts, stores
            materials and support equipment for operation and rehabilitation.
